conclusion: Apply the first law of thermodynamics: ΔU = Q - W.
The work done by the gas is W = -10 J.
From state A to B, volume remains constant (V = V0), temperature increases from T0 to 2T0.
Process A to B is isochoric, so W_AB = 0 J.
Since actual work done is -10 J, use that value directly.
From state B to C, extension line passes through the origin.
Process B to C is isochoric, so work done is zero.
Total work done by the gas is -10 J.
Using ΔU = Q - W, rearrange to find Q = ΔU + 10.
For an ideal gas, ΔU depends only on temperature change.
C_V = (3/2)R for an ideal monatomic gas.
Without specific values, assume heat absorbed Q accounts for entire work done.
Heat absorbed by the gas in process A to B is Q = 10 J.
